Description: Recent studies have shown that disruption of domain boundary or distal regulatory elements can lead to altered gene expression and contributes to pathogenesis in cancer. Furthermore, structural variations (SVs), including inversions, deletions, duplications, and translocations, are a hallmark of most cancer genomes. SVs can disrupt the 3D genome structure and induce the misregulation of critical cancer genes through the formation of “neo-TADs” and “enhancer hijacking.” In this session, we will discuss the latest progress on the methods and our understanding of the role of altered 3D genome organization in cancer.
Location: New Orleans Theater B, Convention Center
SearchResultBody: MW014. Three-dimensional Genome Organization is Important for Proper Gene Regulation and Normal Cell Functions
SearchResultFooter: New Orleans Theater B, Convention Center
Title: Three-dimensional Genome Organization is Important for Proper Gene Regulation and Normal Cell Functions
